children.name: newspaper
children.definition: a set of large folded sheets of printed paper containing news, articles, pictures, advertisements etc which is sold daily or weekly:
examples: She had read about it in the newspaper.

children.name: read a newspaper
examples: Which newspaper do you read?

children.name: get a newspaper
children.definition: buy one regularly
examples: We don’t get a newspaper; we tend to watch the news on TV.

children.name: see/read sth in the newspaper
examples: I saw in the newspaper that he had died.

children.name: appear in a newspaper
examples: Her photo appeared in all the newspapers.

children.name: a newspaper reports sth
children.definition: has an article on something
examples: The newspapers reported that the police were treating the death as a suicide.

children.name: a national newspaper
examples: The story was in all the national newspapers.

children.name: a local newspaper
examples: The store advertises in the local newspaper.

children.name: a daily/weekly/Sunday newspaper
children.definition: one that is published every day/week/Sunday
examples: Do you get a daily newspaper?

children.name: a tabloid newspaper
children.definition: a small-sized newspaper, especially one with not much serious news
examples: Their wedding made the headlines in all the tabloid newspapers.

children.name: a quality newspaperBritish English
children.definition: a newspaper with a lot of serious news and good writing
examples: The story has not been given as much coverage in the quality newspapers.

children.name: a newspaper article/report/story
examples: I read quite an interesting newspaper report on the war.

children.name: a newspaper headline‘
examples: Wine is good for you’ announced a recent newspaper headline.

children.name: a newspaper column
children.definition: a regular article in a newspaper written by a particular journalist
examples: She writes a regular newspaper column about gardening.

children.name: a newspaper clipping/cutting
children.definition: a story cut out of a newspaper
examples: I found some old newspaper cuttings of the band's first concert in Liverpool.

children.name: a newspaper reporter
examples: She was fed up with being followed by newspaper reporters.

children.name: a newspaper editor
examples: Newspaper editors have a lot of power.

children.name: a newspaper proprietorBritish English
children.definition: owner
examples: Ultimately, it’s the newspaper proprietor who decides what goes into the newspaper.

children.name: a series of newspaper articles about life in Cuba
glossy magazine
children.definition: /glossiesUK  a magazine for women printed on shiny paper, that has lots of photographs of fashionable clothes, and advertisements for beauty products: tạp chí giấy bóng
examples: Cosmopolitan, the original glossy for young women
the glossiesUK these magazines considered as a group
We’ve seen her golden smile and her figure in the glossies again and again.

children.name: broadsheet
children.definition: UK a serious newspaper printed on large sheets of paper, with news about politics, finance, and foreign affairs: báo khổ rộng

children.name: broadsheets such as The Times and The Telegraph
examples: Broadsheets are aimed at an educated middle and upper-class readership.

children.name: tabloid
children.definition: a newspaper that does not contain much serious news, but has stories about famous people, sport, sex etc - use this especially about newspapers that you think are not serious enough: báo khổ nhỏ (lá cải, đăng tin vắn)
examples: She claimed that she had had an affair with the President, and sold her story to the tabloids.
The tabloids are full of stories about her and her boyfriend.
tabloid[attri]
tabloid journalists
a tabloid newspaper
the tabloid press

children.name: paper
children.definition: a newspaper. In everyday English, people often saypaperrather thannewspaper:
examples: Have you seen today’s paper?
You’ll read about it in tomorrow’s papers.

children.name: a local paper
examples: You could try putting an advert in the local paper.

children.name: a national paper
examples: The story had been in all the national papers.

children.name: a daily paper
examples: Which of these daily papers do you usually read?

children.name: a
examples: Sunday paperI only get a Sunday paper if I’ve got lots of spare time.

children.name: an evening paper
examples: Ian usually buys an evening paper on his way home.

children.name: a tabloid paper
children.definition: one with small pages, especially one without much serious news
examples: Don’t believe everything you read in the tabloid papers.

children.name: a broadsheet paper
children.definition: one with large pages, usually one containing serious news
examples: Tabloid newspapers are usually about half the size of a broadsheet paper.

children.name: a quality paperBritish English
children.definition: one intended for educated readers
examples: Readers of quality papers, such as the Telegraph and the Guardian, are mainly employed in professional jobs.

children.name: each of a regular series of publications.
issue
children.definition: a magazine or newspaper printed for a particular day, week, or month: số ra
examples: issue of
the December issue of the magazine
the January issue of Newsweek
the current/latest issue
Have you seen the latest issue?

children.name: all newspapers and journalists as a group
the press
children.definition: UK newspapers or journalists viewed collectively: báo chí, giới báo chí
examples: To judge from the press, the concert was a great success.
The press have been very nasty about him.

children.name: the national press
examples: There was very little about the incident in the national press.

children.name: the local press
examples: Evening classes are advertised in the local press.

children.name: the
examples: British/American etc pressThe British press have blamed other countries for North Sea pollution.

children.name: the foreign press
examples: African countries want the foreign press to report African affairs.

children.name: the quality press
children.definition: newspapers intended for educated people
examples: The book received excellent reviews in the quality press.

children.name: the tabloid/popular press
children.definition: popular newspapers that have a lot of news about famous people etc, rather than serious news
examples: He regularly appeared in the tabloid press alongside well-known actresses.

children.name: the gutter pressBritish English
children.definition: newspapers that print shocking stories about people’s private lives
examples: The gutter press enjoyed printing the sensational story.

children.name: talk/speak to the press
examples: He is reluctant to talk to the press.

children.name: tell the press sth‘
examples: It was a really tough decision,’ she told the press.

children.name: leak sth to the press
children.definition: give them secret information in an unofficial way
examples: The confidential report was leaked to the press.

children.name: the freedom of the press
children.definition: the right of newspapers to publish news and opinions without being controlled by the government

children.name: in the pressin the newspapers
examples: There was a lot of speculation in the press that the Prime Minister was about to resign.

children.name: notify the pressđưa tin cho báo chí
examples: Palace staff waited several hours before notifying the press about the King’s condition.
The freedom of the press must be upheld.

children.name: the nationals
children.definition: the newspapers that give news about the whole country where they are printed, in contrast to local newspapers:
examples: The results of the nationwide survey became headlines in the nationals.

children.name: the dailies
children.definition: the daily newspapers: báo ra hàng ngày
examples: The dailies reported the story.
The story was covered in all the national dailies.

children.name: press
children.definition: coverage in newspapers and magazines:

children.name: there's no point in demonstrating if you don't get any press
examples: What kind of press did his play get?
get/be given a bad pressto be criticized in the newspapers or on radio or television :
The government's policy on mental health care is getting an increasingly bad press.

children.name: the government has had a bad press for years
examples: get/have a good pressto be praised in the newspapers or on radio or television :
Our recycling policy is getting a good press.
press reportsAccording to press reports, he was suffering from exhaustion.
press coverage(= articles in newspapers)The event received a lot of press coverage.
a press photographerA group of press photographers was waiting for her outside.

children.name: brochure
children.definition: a type of small magazinethat contains pictures and information on a product or a company: tạp chí nhỏ (quảng cáo)
examples: a holiday brochure

children.name: comic
children.definition: / comic bookUS  a magazine for children that tells a story using comic strips: tạp chí truyện tranh

children.name: journal
children.definition: a serious magazine produced for professional people or those with a particular interest: tạp chí chuyên đề, tập san
examples: a medical/trade journal
the British Medical Journal

children.name: magazine
children.definition: a large, thin book with a paper cover, often printed on shiny paper, which contains stories, articles, photographs, and sometimes also news: tạp chí
examples: I bought some magazines for the trip - Cosmopolitan and Vanity Fair.
Hillary Clinton is featured on the cover of this week’s Time magazine.
She’s the editor of a popular women’s magazine.
a magazine article
She glanced over the magazine racks.
fashion/computer etc magazine
a glossy fashion magazine
women’s/men’s magazinea magazine intended especially for women/men
a model turned TV presenter, who has been on the cover of all the men’s magazines
